commentary_on_process:
To solve the problem, I first identified the relevant information in the given context. The context mentions that the percentage of Gaelic speakers in Kilmuir, Skye is 46%, which means that the percentage of people who don't speak Gaelic in Kilmuir, Skye is 100% - 46% = 54%. Therefore, the answer to the question is that the percentage of people in Skye who don't speak Gaelic is 70.6%. 

To solve the problem better, I could have double-checked my calculations to ensure that I didn't make any errors. Additionally, I could have looked for more information in the context to confirm my answer.
final_answer: The percentage of people in Skye who don't speak Gaelic is 70.6%.
problem_text:
Context:
Gaelic continues to decline in its traditional heartland. Between 2001 and 2011, the absolute number of Gaelic speakers fell sharply in the Western Isles (−1,745), Argyll & Bute (−694), and Highland (−634). The drop in Stornoway, the largest parish in the Western Isles by population, was especially acute, from 57.5% of the population in 1991 to 43.4% in 2011. The only parish outside the Western Isles over 40% Gaelic-speaking is Kilmuir, Skye in Northern Isle of Skye at 46%. The islands in the Inner Hebrides with significant percentages of Gaelic speakers are Tiree (38.3%), Raasay (30.4%), Skye (29.4%), Lismore, Scotland (26.9%), Colonsay (20.2%), and Islay (19.0%).

Question:
How many in percent of people in Skye don't speak Gaelic?
